definitions.definition: to move forwards lightly and quickly making a little jump with each step

examples.text: She skipped happily along beside me.
Lambs were skipping about in the fields.
Scott practically skipped home, he was so happy.
She skipped off to play with her friends.
She skipped to the door.

definitions.definition: to jump over a rope which is held at both ends by yourself or by two other people and is passed again and again over your head and under your feet

examples.text: He skips for about 20 minutes a day.
The girls were skipping in the playground.
She likes to skip rope as a warm-up.

definitions.definition: to not do something that you usually do or should do

examples.text: I often skip breakfast altogether.
She decided to **skip class** that afternoon.

definitions.definition: to leave out something that would normally be the next thing that you would do, read, etc.
definitions.sensetop: skip somethingskip over somethingskip to something

examples.text: You can skip the next chapter if you have covered the topic in class.
What I saw made my heart skip a beat.
I skipped over the last part of the book.
I suggest we skip to the last item on the agenda.

definitions.definition: to move from one place to another or from one subject to another very quickly

examples.text: She kept skipping from one topic of conversation to another.

definitions.definition: to leave a place secretly or suddenly

examples.text: The bombers skipped the country shortly after the blast.

definitions.definition: to make a flat stone jump across the surface of water

examples.text: The boys were skipping stones across the pond.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody has a sudden feeling of fear, excitement, etc.

examples.text: My heart missed a beat when I saw who it was.

definitions.definition: to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial

examples.text: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody rudely that you do not want to talk about something or repeat what you have said

examples.text: ‘What were you saying?’ ‘Oh, skip it!’

wordOrigin: verb Middle English: probably of Scandinavian origin.
